FedDKD: Federated Learning with
Decentralized Knowledge Distillation

Xinjia Li, Boyu Chen and Wenlian Lu∗
{20110180037, 17110180037, wenlian}@fudan.edu.cn ∗Corresponding author.
Abstract

The performance of federated learning in neural networks is generally influenced by the heterogeneity of the data distribution. For a well-performing global model, taking a weighted average of the local models, as done by most existing federated learning algorithms, may not guarantee consistency with local models in the space of neural network maps. In this paper, we propose a novel framework of federated learning equipped with the process of decentralized knowledge distillation (FedDKD) (i.e., without data on the server). The FedDKD introduces a module of decentralized knowledge distillation (DKD) to distill the knowledge of the local models to train the global model by approaching the neural network map average based on the metric of divergence defined in the loss function, other than only averaging parameters as done in literature. Numeric experiments on various heterogeneous datasets reveal that FedDKD outperforms the state-of-the-art methods with more efficient communication and training in a few DKD steps, especially on some extremely heterogeneous datasets.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, knowledge distillation, heterogeneous data, data-free algorithm

I Introduction

Data privacy and data security have attracted increasing attention with the widespread application of deep learning in real life, such as smartphones, Internet of Things (IoT) devices, and digital health. Thus, federated learning [1, 2, 3], which focuses on the challenge of training a global model while leaving the users’ private data on their device, has been widely used to train models across mobile phones and IoT devices.

The typical methods of federated learning including FedAvg [1], FedProx [4], and FedMAX [5], follow the pipeline proposed by FedAvg. The server collects parameters or gradients from local models and updates the weights of the global model iteratively with the weighted average of the local models. Generally, federated learning employs stochastic gradient descent (SGD) to optimize the local models on the clients. It is well known that the SGD requests independently identically distributed samples to guarantee the stochastic gradient to be an unbiased estimate of the full gradient [6, 7, 8]. However, data subsets on each client are heterogeneously distributed in many situations, where the client datasets have different data sources (e.g., medical radiology images from various hospitals [9]), or datasets may come from the same source but have a heterogeneous label distribution [1, 4, 10, 6, 11].

Previous literature has shown that the performance of federated learning is significantly reduced by data heterogeneity [6], and diverse methods have been proposed to reduce the difference in local models in the parameter space and strengthen the local training on each client. FedProx proposed a proximal term for each local loss to weaken the influence of the local bias, and FedMAX used the Kullback-Leibler (KL) divergence between the activation vector and uniform distribution over the activation vectors, where the activation vector in their work is the last fully connected layer. However, some experiments [10, 12] have revealed that the FedMAX and FedProx perform worse than the FedAvg on several federated learning tasks, reflecting that adding a penalty term in local training is inefficient enough to solve the heterogeneity problem.

Beyond that, knowledge distillation (KD) has recently been used to reduce the difference in outputs between local and global models. Some researchers [13, 14] have assumed that a public dataset is available on the central server to optimize the global model. In particular, FedDF [11] stores unlabeled datasets or artificially generates datasets on the server and teaches the global model with the ensemble model from clients based on these data. However, the public dataset on the server is not always available or consistent with clients in applications.

Other research, such as FedDistill [15] and FedGen [16], has introduced inductive bias on local models by considering the loss involved other client information and followed FedAvg to obtain global parameters. These data-free methods do not need any public dataset and attempt to mitigate the effects of data heterogeneity only in local models, whose effectiveness is an essential prerequisite for the global model. Besides, FedGen requires an extra well-designed generator in the server, of which the effectiveness greatly determines how well the global model performs. Recently, FedNTD [17] and FedGKD [18] distill the knowledge of global model for local models, which add the an extra distillation loss when training in the local clients.

In addition, several studies have attempted to eliminate the heterogeneity of local datasets by re-balancing the local data distribution. In Astraea [19], they proposed a mediator, grouping the clients to re-balance the probability distributions of local clients and achieve partial equilibrium. A more direct method is distributing a small subset of global data containing a uniform distribution over classes from the cloud to the clients [6]. However, these methods require detailed knowledge of the local distribution or available central datasets.

Due to the overparameterization of neural networks, it has been argued that averaging the parameters is not an optimal approach to averaging the local model in the function space. For instance, in FedMA [10], the authors presented the argument that the permutation invariance of neural network architectures partially explains why averaging the local parameters is a naive and not optimal method to obtain global parameters, despite its practical performance [1, 5]. Consider a basic fully connected neural network y^=σ​(x​W(1)​Π)​Π​W(2)^𝑦𝜎𝑥superscript𝑊1ΠΠsuperscript𝑊2\hat{y}=\sigma(xW^{(1)}\Pi)\Pi W^{(2)}, where {W(1),W(2)}superscript𝑊1superscript𝑊2\{W^{(1)},W^{(2)}\} are optimal weights, and ΠΠ\Pi is a permutation matrix [10]. If both local models respectively obtain the optimal weights {W(1)​Πj,Πj​W(2)}superscript𝑊1subscriptΠ𝑗subscriptΠ𝑗superscript𝑊2\{W^{(1)}\Pi_{j},\Pi_{j}W^{(2)}\} and {W(1)​Πj′,Πj′​W(2)}superscript𝑊1subscriptΠsuperscript𝑗′subscriptΠsuperscript𝑗′superscript𝑊2\{W^{(1)}\Pi_{j^{\prime}},\Pi_{j^{\prime}}W^{(2)}\}, then averaging the weights is almost impossible to obtain optimal weights given that Πj≠Πj′subscriptΠ𝑗subscriptΠsuperscript𝑗′\Pi_{j}\neq\Pi_{j^{\prime}}. However, optimal function mapping still results if the two local models are averaged in the function space (i.e., averaging the same two function mappings in this example).

In this paper, we propose a novel federated learning scheme, FedDKD, introducing a module of decentralized knowledge distillation (DKD) to average the local models on the function space instead of the parameter space. Without shared data on the server, the DKD enables the global model to integrate knowledge learned from local datasets to approach the average of local models in the function space. Unlike the existing federated learning methods with knowledge distillation, FedDKD is a data-free method, which means there is no public datasets on the server and does not require an extra generator to generate artifical datasets, optimizing the local models and DKD module alternately. Different from other data-free federated learning methods based on distillation learning which distill the knowledge of the global model for the local models separately (Fig. 1(a)), FedDKD jointly distills the knowledge of the local models for global model by collecting the knowledge from the clients and updates the global model on the server (Fig. 1 (b)) to obtain the average in function space rather than that in parameter space. The FedDKD can efficiently eliminate the damage caused by the heterogeneity of local datasets and help determine a better global model in the function space compared to directly taking the weighted average of local models.

Numerical experiments on diverse heterogeneous datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of this method to achieve better test accuracy. Moreover, FedDKD achieves training and communication efficiency on some extremely heterogeneous datasets. The DKD module can work as an additional plug-in module for diverse state-of-the-art federated learning technologies to improve their performance.

Relation to the weighted averaging method. Moreover, for the linear model, Corollary 1 is a linear form of Proposition 2. The detailed proof of Proposition 2 and Corollary 1 are provided in Supplementary Materials -B.

Corollary 1

If Φ​(x;w)=Φ​(x;(A,b))=A​x+bΦ𝑥𝑤Φ𝑥𝐴𝑏𝐴𝑥𝑏\Phi(x;w)=\Phi(x;(A,b))=Ax+b, where x∈ℝn𝑥superscriptℝ𝑛x\in\mathbbm{R}^{n}, A∈ℝm,n𝐴superscriptℝ𝑚𝑛A\in\mathbbm{R}^{m,n},b∈ℝm𝑏superscriptℝ𝑚b\in\mathbbm{R}^{m}, d​i​v​(u,v)=‖u−v‖22𝑑𝑖𝑣𝑢𝑣subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑢𝑣22div(u,v)=\|u-v\|^{2}_{2}, and 𝒟k,k=1,⋯,Kformulae-sequencesubscript𝒟𝑘𝑘1⋯𝐾\mathcal{D}_{k},~{}k=1,\cdots,K are all homogeneous datasets, then one of the solutions of Eq. (6) is that w^=∑k=1Kqk​wk,^𝑤superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝑤𝑘\hat{w}=\sum_{k=1}^{K}{q_{k}w_{k}},which is the weighted average of the local models.

For a heterogeneous dataset, which is a more general case in federated learning, there is a high probability that Proposition 2 and Corollary 1 do not hold because Hk​(w∗),k=1,2,⋯,Kformulae-sequencesubscript𝐻𝑘superscript𝑤𝑘12⋯𝐾H_{k}(w^{*}),k=1,2,\cdots,K may be very different. As a result, for heterogeneous datasets, taking the weighted average of local models can not guarantee the optimality of the global model. Thus, we need an algorithm to minimize L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} in Eq. (3) to determine a better global model.

III The Proposed Approach: FedDKD

We consider a typical federated learning problem with the disjoint datasets 𝒟k:={(xk,i,yk,i)}i=1nkassignsubscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖𝑖1subscript𝑛𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}:=\{(x_{k,i},y_{k,i})\}_{i=1}^{n_{k}}, where (xk,i,yk,i)∈ℝs×ℝsubscript𝑥𝑘𝑖subscript𝑦𝑘𝑖superscriptℝ𝑠ℝ(x_{k,i},y_{k,i})\in\mathbbm{R}^{s}\times\mathbbm{R} on client k𝑘k . The local model Φ​(x;wk)Φ𝑥subscript𝑤𝑘\Phi(x;w_{k}) on client k𝑘k and global model Φ​(x;w)Φ𝑥𝑤\Phi(x;w) are defined with the same neural network architecture.

III-A FL with DKD: FedDKD

To learn the central mapping of local models in function space, we specify the divergence in Eq. (1) as a variant of total variation distance to measure the distribution distance between the ground truth and prediction of the global model.

Proposition 1 in Section II notes that with the square of the measurement of total variation distance, Eq. (1) can be optimized by minimizing the upper bound L1′+L2′subscriptsuperscript𝐿′1subscriptsuperscript𝐿′2L^{\prime}_{1}+L^{\prime}_{2} based on the KL divergence, from which we can easily optimize a classifier with the derived cross-entropy loss. Minimizing L1′superscriptsubscript𝐿1′L_{1}^{\prime} trains the local models in parallel on client k𝑘k, whereas minimizing L2′superscriptsubscript𝐿2′L_{2}^{\prime} optimizes the objective in the DKD module to teach the global model using well-trained local models.

Motivated by the above, we propose a federated learning framework equipped with DKD, named FedDKD, composed of two stages per round. Each client is trained locally on private data and ground truth labels (min⁡L1′superscriptsubscript𝐿1′\min L_{1}^{\prime}). Then the global model learns from local models in the DKD module, for which the corresponding objective is formulated as follows:

∑k∈𝒞qknk​∑(x,y)∈𝒟kLC​E​(Φ​(x;wk),Φ​(x;w)),subscript𝑘𝒞subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝑛𝑘subscript𝑥𝑦subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝐿𝐶𝐸Φ𝑥subscript𝑤𝑘Φ𝑥𝑤\sum_{k\in\mathcal{C}}\frac{q_{k}}{n_{k}}\sum_{(x,y)\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}L_{CE}(\Phi(x;w_{k}),\Phi(x;w)), (8)

where ∑k∈𝒞qk=1subscript𝑘𝒞subscript𝑞𝑘1\sum_{k\in\mathcal{C}}q_{k}=1, and LC​E​(⋅,⋅)subscript𝐿𝐶𝐸⋅⋅L_{CE}(\cdot,\cdot) is the cross-entropy loss function. We define the process to minimize L1′superscriptsubscript𝐿1′L_{1}^{\prime} followed by minimizing L2′superscriptsubscript𝐿2′L_{2}^{\prime} as a DKD round. When it does not cause ambiguity, we call it a round for short.

The optimal solution of minimizing Eq. (8) provides the center of all client models Φ​(x;wk)Φ𝑥subscript𝑤𝑘\Phi(x;w_{k}), k=1,⋯,K𝑘1⋯𝐾k=1,\cdots,K, in the function space, rather than the center of the parameters of the local models in the parameter space according to the (possibly weighted) Euclidean space.

Pipeline of FedDKD. We summarize the training pipeline of FedDKD in Algorithm 1. In each DKD round t𝑡t, we first sample a subset 𝒞tsubscript𝒞𝑡\mathcal{C}_{t} of clients, of which the parameters are initialized with wt−1∗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑡1w_{t-1}^{*} (i.e., a global model estimation in the last DKD round). Then, we optimize the local models using local data in their clients in parallel for E𝐸E local epochs. Afterward, with fixed local models, taking their weighted average, the global model is updated by minimizing Eq. (8) for J𝐽J DKD steps to approach the ideal global model.

In detail, with the empirical distribution of the sampled local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} in client k𝑘k, we use the SGD to estimate the gradient of the sub-term 1nk​∑(x,y)∈𝒟kLC​E​(Φ​(x;wk),Φ​(x;w))1subscript𝑛𝑘subscript𝑥𝑦subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝐿𝐶𝐸Φ𝑥subscript𝑤𝑘Φ𝑥𝑤\frac{1}{n_{k}}\sum_{(x,y)\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}L_{CE}(\Phi(x;w_{k}),\Phi(x;w)). The algorithm to calculate the gradient on each client is DKDSGD (Algorithm 2). In each DKD step j𝑗j, the local model acts as a sub-teacher. In addition, DKDSGD calculates the gradients of w¯t,jsubscript¯𝑤𝑡𝑗\bar{w}_{t,j} on the mini-batch drawn from the local distribution, and sends the gradients to the server. Let qk=1/|𝒞t|,k∈𝒞tformulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑘1subscript𝒞𝑡𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡q_{k}=1/|\mathcal{C}_{t}|,k\in\mathcal{C}_{t}, and the server collects all gradients ∇dk,j,k∈𝒞t∇subscript𝑑𝑘𝑗𝑘subscript𝒞𝑡\nabla d_{k,j},k\in\mathcal{C}_{t} from local clients and averages them to obtain the gradient of Eq. (8) concerning w¯t,jsubscript¯𝑤𝑡𝑗\bar{w}_{t,j}. After acquiring the gradient for Eq. (8), the global model updates with the DKD learning rate γ𝛾\gamma and distributes the new global parameters to the local clients. In FedDKD (Algorithm 1), Lines 7 to 11 represent the DKD module.

Benefits of FedDKD. Minimizing L1′superscriptsubscript𝐿1′L_{1}^{\prime} and L2′superscriptsubscript𝐿2′L_{2}^{\prime} in Eq. (5) alternately, FedDKD minimizes the upper bound of the distance between the ground truth map and global model in the function space. The keypoint of FedDKD is minimizing both terms, whereas most of the federated learning algorithms only optimize L1′superscriptsubscript𝐿1′L_{1}^{\prime}. Eliminating the damage caused by the heterogeneity of the local datasets and reparameterization invariance of neural networks on the map functions by minimizing L2′superscriptsubscript𝐿2′L_{2}^{\prime}, the DKD module helps FedDKD search for a better global model for the current DKD round. It sends back better initial parameters for the next DKD round for local training.

III-B Extensions of FedDKD

We note that the framework of FedDKD can be a general framework of federated learning because the DKD process can be a plug-in for other federated learning methods.

FedDKD_MAX. We can replace the local training scheme of FedDKD with that of FedMAX [5] to enable similar activation vectors across various clients. In detail, we add a loss term β​1B​∑i=1NK​L​(ai∥U)𝛽1𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁𝐾𝐿conditionalsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑈\beta\frac{1}{B}\sum_{i=1}^{N}KL(a_{i}\|U) to the cross-entropy loss in local training on the clients, where aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i} is the activation vector of sample i𝑖i, β𝛽\beta is a hyper-parameter, and U𝑈U is the uniform distribution over the activation vectors. We call the alternative algorithm FedDKD_MAX.

FedDKD_BN. We combine FedDKD with FedBN [9] to handle the neural network models with batch normalization (BN) layers, called FedDKD_BN, where local models have their own BN layers whose parameters should remain. Thus, for FedDKD_BN, the objective of the DKD module is revised as follows:

minw′∈ℝd​∑k∈𝒞qknk​∑(x,y)∈𝒟kLC​E​(Φk​(x;wk),Φ​(x;w′,wkB​N)),subscriptsuperscript𝑤′superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝑘𝒞subscript𝑞𝑘subscript𝑛𝑘subscript𝑥𝑦subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝐿𝐶𝐸subscriptΦ𝑘𝑥subscript𝑤𝑘Φ𝑥superscript𝑤′superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝐵𝑁\min_{w^{\prime}\in\mathbbm{R}^{d}}\sum_{k\in\mathcal{C}}\frac{q_{k}}{n_{k}}\sum_{(x,y)\in\mathcal{D}_{k}}L_{CE}(\Phi_{k}(x;w_{k}),\Phi(x;w^{\prime},w_{k}^{BN})),

where wkB​Nsuperscriptsubscript𝑤𝑘𝐵𝑁w_{k}^{BN} is the parameter of the BN layers of the local model k𝑘k, and w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} represents other parameter. In the DKD module of FedDKD_BN, only the weight w′superscript𝑤′w^{\prime} is updated. Based on FedBN, FedDKD_BN takes weighted average parameters, excluding the B​N𝐵𝑁BN layers, as the initial global model of the DKD module. Please refer to Supplementary Materials -C and -D for more details on these extensions.

IV Experiment

We perform many numerical experiments on the EMNIST/FEMNIST [22, 5], CIFAR10/CIFAR100 [23], and a multi-sources digits dataset, compared with several mainstream methods, including FedAvg [1], FedProx [4], FedMAX [5], and FedBN [9]. An experiment on EMNIST compares several state-of-the-art data-free KD approaches, such as FedGen [16] and FedDistill [15]. Overall, we experiment on the following sufficient settings:

  • •

    various datasets, such as EMNIST, FEMNIST, CIFAR10, CIFAR100, and multi-sources digits datasets;

  • •

    various heterogeneities: part of the categories, Dirichlet distribution with different α𝛼\alpha values, and different data sources;

  • •

    different activation ratios of clients: 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, and 1.0; and

  • •

    different local epochs.

We also experimented with the following sufficient metrics:

  • •

    test accuracy,

  • •

    costs to reach the target accuracy,

  • •

    test accuracy under the same communication cost, and

  • •

    test accuracy under the same training steps (×103absentsuperscript103\times 10^{3}).

In addition, we use different models with or without BN layers.

IV-A FEMNIST

In this section, we demonstrate the superiority of the FedDKD in communication efficiency and convergence speed when handling heterogeneity datasets. Moreover, we display the power of the DKD module equipped with other state-of-the-art training techniques for the local models.

We compare FedMAX with the proposed method in experiments on the dataset FEMNIST [5], which is divided into heterogeneous local datasets. We randomly choose 666 out of 262626 classes to allocate to each agent. We use 50%percent5050\% of the raw training dataset as the federated learning training dataset and 10%percent1010\% as the validation dataset. The test dataset remains the same as the raw dataset.

We set the number of clients to 202020, and the activation ratio of clients per DKD round is 0.25,0.5,0.250.50.25,0.5, or 0.750.750.75. The number of local training epochs is 555 or 151515, and the total DKD rounds T𝑇T is 660660660. For FedProx and FedMAX, we perform the optimal search for the best parameters μ𝜇\mu and β𝛽\beta, respectively. For FedDKD and FedDKD_MAX, we set DKD step J𝐽J to 10, and the initial DKD learning rate γ𝛾\gamma is 0.20.20.2 with a decay rate of 0.98 per DKD round. We run each experiment three times with different random seeds to obtain credible results. The test accuracy is based on the best model for the validation dataset. Please refer to Supplementary Materials -E for more details.

Reaching a target quickly and efficiently. Three metrics are considered to reach a target test accuracy, including the DKD round, communication round, and average training step per activated client. In addition, FedDKD requires much fewer DKD rounds and training steps in all experiment settings and is efficient in communication when the activation ratio c𝑐c is 0.5 or 0.75, as the DKD module can estimate the global distribution of the dataset better. For example, if the activation ratio c=0.75𝑐0.75c=0.75 and the local training epoch E=5𝐸5E=5, FedDKD can achieve a 90.5%percent90.590.5\% test accuracy with only 5%percent55\% of the DKD rounds and training steps and 50%percent5050\% of the communication rounds compared to those in other mainstream methods, as Table I presents. Combining the DKD module with FedMAX, FedDKD_MAX requires fewer training steps and DKD rounds when c=0.25𝑐0.25c=0.25 and E=5𝐸5E=5.

Best performance. Training for 660660660 DKD rounds, FedDKD and FedDKD_MAX outperform all the other methods by around 0.75%,1.0%percent0.75percent1.00.75\%,1.0\%, and 1.5%percent1.51.5\% on test accuracy for c=0.25,0.5𝑐0.250.5c=0.25,0.5 and 0.750.750.75, respectively (Table II). With more clients activated in each communication round, FedDKD can better estimate the global distribution of the datasets and have more advantages than other methods on test accuracy. To compete with other methods fairly in communication cost, we also present the test accuracy when FedDKD and FedDKD_MAX are only trained for 606060 DKD rounds. In this setting, all methods communicate for 660 rounds with their local clients, and the communication cost in each round remains the same. However, the average training steps of FedDKD and FedDKD_MAX is only about 10%percent1010\% of that of the baselines. The results reveal that FedDKD can achieve a better test accuracy with the same training steps and fewer DKD rounds. When the activation ratio c𝑐c increases, with the same communication cost, FedDKD can achieve better performance with fewer training steps and DKD rounds.

Efficient communication. The FedDKD method is efficient in communication when the activation ratio c𝑐c is 0.50.50.5 or 0.750.750.75. With the same communication rounds and communication costs (Figure 2), the proposed method achieves the best test accuracy. For detailed results for E=15𝐸15E=15, please refer to Supplementary Materials -E. With the same communication rounds, FedDKD and FedDKD_MAX only run for 1/111111/11 of the DKD round and about 10%percent1010\% of the training steps of the baselines. Thus, the proposed methods may be weaker than other methods when the communication rounds are too few.

Efficient training. The proposed methods require a fewer more training step per DKD round in the DKD module. However, the improvement is not due to more training steps, and FedDKD is training-efficient. With the same training steps, FedDKD and FedDKD_MAX display a considerable improvement in test accuracy for the baselines (Figure 3). In comparing the proposed methods and the baselines, many unnecessary training steps occur for the baselines, and more communication is the key factor in pursuing a better performance. Please refer to Supplementary Materials -E for the results of E=15𝐸15E=15 and E=5,c=0.25formulae-sequence𝐸5𝑐0.25E=5,c=0.25.

IV-B CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100

In this experiment, we consider a more challenging task of the datasets CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 [23]. Following the previous work [10], we divide CIFAR-10 into K𝐾K clients by sampling pr∼DirK​(α)similar-tosubscriptp𝑟subscriptDir𝐾𝛼\textbf{p}_{r}\sim\text{Dir}_{K}(\alpha) from a Dirichlet distribution and allocating a pr,ksubscriptp𝑟𝑘\textbf{p}_{r,k} proportion of the training instances of class r𝑟r to the local client k𝑘k. In the experiments, α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1, and the local datasets are extremely heterogeneous. We use the same neural network model (i.e. VGG-9) without BN layers, as in [10]. We set 10%percent1010\% of the raw training set as the validation set and the others as the training set.

For federated learning experiments, we set the number of clients to 161616, and the client fraction C𝐶C is 1.01.01.0 (i.e., all clients will be involved in the local update per DKD round). To achieve a trade-off between performance and communication costs, we set DKD step J to 333. The DKD learning rate ηdsubscript𝜂𝑑\eta_{d} is 0.080.080.08 with a decay rate of 0.990.990.99 per DKD round for CIFAR-10 and ηd=0.06subscript𝜂𝑑0.06\eta_{d}=0.06 for CIFAR-100. The test accuracy and corresponding DKD and communication rounds are based on the best model for the validation set. Please refer to Supplementary Materials -F for the details of experiment settings.

For CIFAR-10 (Table III), with 350350350 DKD rounds, the proposed FedDKD improves the test performance by almost 5%percent55\% of the baselines at the expense of similar training costs and only four times the communication cost. With a similar communication cost and much fewer training steps (i.e., 24.4%percent24.424.4\% of the training steps of the baselines), FedDKD achieves almost 2%percent22\% improvement on the test accuracy in 878787 DKD rounds. To reach the same test accuracy target (i.e., 74%percent7474\%) with less communication cost, FedDKD requires only about 20%percent2020\% of the DKD rounds and 20%percent2020\% of the training steps of the baseline cost.

For CIFAR-100 (Table IV), where it is more challenging to handle heterogeneity because the number of categories is 100100100, local teachers have low test accuracy (less than 40%percent4040\%) in the first 303030 DKD rounds, and the knowledge is too incomplete to teach the student model. Thus, the DKD step is not executed for the first 303030 DKD rounds in this experiment. In addition, FedDKD improves the global model by about 2%percent22\% regarding test accuracy. It only needs 1/3131/3 of the DKD round and training steps in other methods to reach the same test accuracy target (i.e., 51.4%) under the same communications, which illustrates the training efficiency of the proposed method. For a fair comparison, we also run FedDKD for 110 DKD rounds (i.e., FedDKD@110), where the number of communication rounds is 350350350. In this case, FedDKD still slightly exceeds the baseline in test accuracy. However, FedDKD only trains about 1/3131/3 of the steps.

The experiments on CIFAR-10/100 illustrate that the proposed method is efficient in much more complex tasks with equal DKD rounds and training steps. With equal communication costs and much fewer training steps, FedDKD exceeds the baselines on test accuracy. The experiments imply that local training is often superfluous for heterogeneous datasets and that more communication is the key to higher performance.

IV-C Knowledge Distillation Algorithms

This subsection compares FedDKD with other data-free federated learning algorithms equipped with KD, such as FedGen and FedDistill.

In FedGen, the server trains a generator to ensemble the client information in a data-free manner and then broadcast to users, regulating local training using the learned knowledge as an inductive bias. Additionally, FedDistill only collects and sends back the average logits of the client models. Following previous research [16], we also share the parameters of the client models as FedAvg for FedDistill, called FedDistill+ to achieve a fair comparison.

The experiments on the EMNIST dataset follow the work in [16]. There are 202020 clients with an active ratio of 50%percent5050\%. The local epoch E=20𝐸20E=20. We use only 10%percent1010\% of the training dataset and all test datasets. To obtain an extremely heterogeneous dataset, we divide the training dataset according to the Dirichlet distribution with α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05 or 0.10.10.1. We maintain the hyper-parameters for the baseline as those in FedGen [16]. For FedDKD, we set the DKD learning rate γ=0.40𝛾0.40\gamma=0.40 with a decay rate of 0.990.990.99 per DKD round and the DKD steps J=3𝐽3J=3. We run each experiment 101010 times.

As Table V lists, FedDKD achieves the best test accuracy and outperforms other methods by about 4.2%percent4.24.2\% when α=0.05𝛼0.05\alpha=0.05 and by 1.7%percent1.71.7\% when α=0.1𝛼0.1\alpha=0.1. In addition, FedDKD does not require a well-designed and well-trained extra generator as in FedGEN but achieves superb performance when the dataset is highly heterogeneous.

IV-D Architecture with the Batch Normalization Layer

In this experiment, we consider the architecture with the BN layer. Most models remove the BN layer in federated learning to average the model better. However, FedBN introduces the BN layer to handle heterogeneous datasets when the local datasets are collected from different sources. This subsection primarily demonstrates the power of the DKD module equipped with other state-of-the-art methods (i.e., FedBN).

Specifically, we use five different digit datasets: SVHN [24], USPS [25], SynthDigits [26], MNIST-M [26], and MNIST [27], with 10% of each dataset allocated to each client with 743743743 training samples for each local model. We use the same neural network model as that in FedBN, with three convolutional layers with BN layers and three full-connected layers with BN layers. Please refer to Supplementary Materials -G for the details of this experiment.

Table VI illustrates that the FedDKD_BN achieves the best test accuracy and outperforms FedAvg by 3.21%, FedProx by 3.14%, FedBN by 0.31%, and FedDKD by 0.58%. Further, FedDKD is slightly weaker than FedBN in test accuracy. However, for FedBN, every local model maintains its BN layer, which means that it has N𝑁N models for N𝑁N clients, sharing most parameters and maintaining the respective batch normalization layer, whereas FedDKD has only a single global model.

The DKD module can work with the model with BN layers. Moreover, combining the technique for FedBN can improve performance. This finding also implies that the DKD module can be a general tool that can be combined with other training methods for local models to improve performance.

V Conclusion

This paper proposes a novel federated learning framework with decentralized knowledge distillation, called FedDKD. Directly averaging the local models is not inherently the best method for the permutation invariance of neural networks and the heterogeneity of local datasets. Thus we emphasize the importance of function space rather than parameter space. Furthermore, FedDKD refines the initial averaging model according to the outputs of local models with KD. The global model is inspired to learn what local models learn, the local data distribution. Experiments on various datasets demonstrate that FedDKD can achieve superb test accuracy and even more efficient communication and faster convergence speeds in some extremely heterogeneous datasets.

In practice, FedDKD requires that the clients continuously stay online several times, which is easy to implement in federated learning and does not increase any privacy risks compared to the universal algorithms. In FedDKD, local training is generally redundant, whereas communication is essential because it helps determine the average in the function space rather than the parameter space for heterogeneous datasets.

Supplementary Materials

-A The proof of Proposition 1

Proof 1

By the triangular inequality of divergence δ𝛿\delta, we have

The proof of Corollary 1

Proof 3

This corollary is a linear form of Corollary 1. The choice of the fixed point w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} in the Taylor approximation is irrelevant. Hence, the effect of different values of w∗superscript𝑤w^{*} in Eq. (7) is only included in O​(‖wk−w∗‖3)+O​(‖w−w∗‖3)𝑂superscriptnormsubscript𝑤𝑘superscript𝑤3𝑂superscriptnorm𝑤superscript𝑤3O(\|w_{k}-w^{*}\|^{3})+O(\|w-w^{*}\|^{3}). However, this term does not exist for the linear model, and the Taylor approximation is precise, proving the correctness of this corollary.

-E Experiments on FEMNIST

Model Architecture. For the experiments on the FEMNIST dataset, we use a ”slimmer” CNN model than that in [5], removing the last two convolutional layers. The employed CNN model has three convolutional layers whose channels are 32, 64, and 64 and two full-connected layers. A rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation layer and max-pooling layer follow each convolutional layer. A ReLU layer activates the output of the first fully connected layer, and the last one yields the output for the model. The details are listed in Table VII.

Detailed Settings and Hyper-parameter Searching. On local training in the clients, the learning rate η𝜂\eta is initialized as 0.10.10.1, and the decay rate is 0.980.980.98 per DKD round. The batch size B𝐵B is 646464. The optimizer is the SGD with momentum, and the weight decay rate is 1​e−31𝑒31e-3 for c=0.25𝑐0.25c=0.25 where E=5𝐸5E=5, and otherwise, is 5​e−45𝑒45e-4.

For FedProx, we perform a grid search with μ∈{0.01,0.1,1,10}𝜇0.010.1110\mu\in\{0.01,0.1,1,10\}. We choose the best one (101010). For FedMAX, we test β∈{1,10,100,1000,10000}𝛽110100100010000\beta\in\{1,10,100,1000,10000\}, and the model with β=10𝛽10\beta=10 achieves the best performance. For FedDKD and FedDKD_MAX, we set the DKD learning rate γ=0.2𝛾0.2\gamma=0.2 with the same decay rate of 0.980.980.98, with DKD steps J=10𝐽10J=10 and a DKD batch size B~~𝐵\tilde{B} of 646464.

Communication-Efficient for E=15𝐸15E=15. We further show our method is communication-efficient when E=15𝐸15E=15 in Figure 4.

Training-Efficient for other settings. We further show our method is Training-efficient when c=0.25𝑐0.25c=0.25 in Figure 5 and 6.

-F Experiments on CIFAR-10/100

Model Architecture For the experiments on the CIFAR-10/100 dataset, we use the same CNN model as that in [10] (i.e., VGG-9), and the details are listed in Table VIII.

Detailed Settings On local training of the experiments on CIFAR-10/100, the number of epochs E𝐸E is 101010, and the batch size B𝐵B is 646464. The optimizer is Adam, with a learning rate of 1​e−31𝑒31e-3 and a weight decay rate of 1​e−41𝑒41e-4. Moreover, the learning rate has a decay rate of 0.990.990.99 per DKD round. The total number of DKD rounds is 350350350.

For FedProx, we search the hyper-parameter μ∈{0.001,0.01,0,1,1,10}𝜇0.0010.0101110\mu\in\{0.001,0.01,0,1,1,10\} and choose the best one (0.01) for both CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100.

For other FedDKD settings, we set DKD batch size B~~𝐵\tilde{B} to 646464 for CIFAR-10, which equals the local training batch size B𝐵B. For CIFAR-100, we enlarge the DKD batch size B~~𝐵\tilde{B} to 256256256 beacause the total number of categories is 100100100.

-G Experiments on Multi-sources digits datasets

Model Architecture. For the experiments on multi-sources digits datasets, we use the same CNN model as that in FedBN. The details are listed in Table IX.

Detailed Settings. For the federated learning settings, the number of clients is 555, and all clients participate in the integration per round. For local training, the number of epochs is 111, and the batch size is 32. The optimizer is SGD with a learning rate of 0.010.010.01 and a decay rate of 0.980.980.98. The total DKD round is 100 in this paper.

For the FedDKD, the DKD learning rate is 0.010.010.01, with a deacy rate of 0.980.980.98. The number of DKD steps is 101010, and the DKD batch size is 10. In each DKD round, the DKD learning rate also has a decay rate of 0.970.970.97 per DKD step.
